original_title: Sri Lanka macro-framework re-assessed by IMF
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – An International Monetary Fund mission currently in Sri Lanka will update the macro framework on which a 3.0 billion US dollar program is based on, but initial observations do not indicate a major deviation from earlier expectations, an official said.

“We will be looking at whether our macro framework is still appropriate or whether they have been such substantial changes that requires revisions,” Peter Breuer, IMF’s Senior Mission Chief for Sri Lanka told reporters in Colombo.
“At the moment we see things more or less developing in line with expectations.
“This is something we will decide at the end of the mission to what extent revisions are needed to the macro-framework that you have seen.”
The IMF has projected a 3.0 percent contraction in the 2023 and a 1.5 percent growth in 2024, and 3.0 and 3.1 percent up to 2027.
Inflation is projected at 15.2 percent by year end and 6.7 percent in 2024.
Sri Lanka is projecting higher growth of as much as 5.0 percent by 2027.
The mission will also assess Sri Lanka’s progress under the program. The first official of the program is due in September with June data.
But there are indicative targets for the March 2023 quarter.
Sri Lanka is trying to complete re-structuring by September.  (Colombo/May16/2023)
